flags.text: This project guide is not managed by MAKE staff.

guide.introduction:
Star trails are the paths left by stars as seen from the earth. As the earth spins, the stars appear to move and circle in the sky.

To capture the star trails you need a camera, a tripod and an automated trigger for your camera. The Arduino, a relay and the camera's remote control will create the automated trigger.
guide.introduction_rendered:
Star trails are the paths left by stars as seen from the earth. As the earth spins, the stars appear to move and circle in the sky.

To capture the star trails you need a camera, a tripod and an automated trigger for your camera. The Arduino, a relay and the camera's remote control will create the automated trigger.

Relevant parts
  • Arduino or clone
  • NPN Transistor
  • Resistor
  • Hook-up wire
  • Relay
  • DSLR camera
  • IR remote control for your camera
  • Tripod
Tools
  • Breadboard
  • Soldering iron

parts.text: IR remote control for your camera

lines.text: The system is powered by 12 volts. The transistor turns the relay on when pin 2 is set to HIGH.
lines.text_raw: The system is powered by 12 volts. The transistor turns the relay on when pin 2 is set to HIGH.

lines.text: This fires the IR remote control that triggers the DSLR.

lines.text: The Arduino code can't be more simple. Just decide the time between photos and put that time after the command that sets pin 2 LOW.
lines.text_raw: The Arduino code can't be more simple. Just decide the time between photos and put that time after the command that sets pin 2 LOW.

lines.text: Remember that your DLSR must have time to take and process the photos. If you set your camera to a 10-second exposure you must have 25 to 200 seconds delay between exposures.
